Absolutely! The National Guard works closely with other agencies like FEMA (Federal Emergency Management Agency) and the American Red Cross during all types of emergencies, including natural disasters. They typically operate under the direction of the governor of the affected state, and they work alongside local and federal agencies to provide effective support to affected communities. 

For example, the National Guard can help FEMA set up emergency shelters, distribute food and water, and provide other essential services for people who have been affected by a disaster. They also have specialized units that can assist with tasks like evacuations, Search and Rescue (SAR) missions, and providing security at critical infrastructure sites. Furthermore, the American Red Cross works closely with the National Guard, especially during relief efforts for natural disasters. The Red Cross often provides additional resources such as volunteers, food, clean-up and support services.

So, the National Guard is an integral part of the emergency management infrastructure in the United States, and collaboration with other agencies, including FEMA and the Red Cross, is critical to their successful response to disasters.
